header.title: A Treatise on Angel Magic
header.category: Western Esotericism, Angel Magic, Grimoire Tradition

central_thesis: The book presents a comprehensive 17th-century system of Angel Magic, primarily derived from the "Treatises of Dr. Rudd," detailing theoretical foundations and practical methods for invoking angels and commanding spirits to visible appearance, integrating elements of Enochian, Solomonic, Hermetic Qabalah, and Astrological Magic.

structure_content.summary: This introduction contextualizes the 'Treatises of Dr. Rudd' manuscripts (Harley 6481-6484), identifying Ms6482 as the core 'Treatise on Angel Magic' compiled by Peter Smart between 1699-1714. It highlights the work's Rosicrucian and Hermetic origins, linking it to the magical traditions of John Dee, Edward Kelley, and Johannes Trithemius, clarifying its purpose as a practical manual for angelic invocation and spirit conjuration.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Ten Names of God, with their Ideas, Orbs, and Hierarchies Largely Explained
structure_content.summary: This chapter establishes the Qabalistic and cosmological framework for angel magic, detailing the ten Divine Names, their corresponding Sephiroth, celestial orbs, and associated angelic orders. It provides the metaphysical structure necessary for understanding the spiritual hierarchy and how various angelic intelligences operate within the cosmos.

structure_content.chapter_title: Anima Mundi - The Soul of the World
structure_content.summary: This section explores the concept of the Anima Mundi (World Soul) as a vital mediating force between the divine and material planes. It outlines its connections to planetary intelligences and their pervasive influence on all earthly phenomena, forming a key philosophical basis for sympathetic magic and the operation of celestial forces.

This segment presents intricate Enochian magic squares, specifically seven planetary tables (Tabulae Sanctae) for Saturn, Jupiter, Mars, Sun, Venus, Mercury, and Moon. Each table lists associated good and evil spirits, divine names, and geomantic figures, serving as essential operative tools for planetary-aligned invocations and the commanding of various entities.

This chapter meticulously details the 72 Angels of the Schemhamphoras, derived from the 216-letter name of God. For each angel, it provides its Hebrew name, a corresponding Biblical verse, and a precise description of its office, specific powers, and sphere of influence, acting as a comprehensive directory for invoking particular angelic assistance.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Names of Some of the Good and Bad Spirits Solomon Made Use of
structure_content.summary: This extensive section lists numerous spirits, categorized as good or bad, along with descriptions of their ranks, typical appearances, the number of legions they command, and their specific abilities. It functions as a practical reference for identifying and understanding the diverse entities encountered and commanded in Solomonic magical operations.

structure_content.chapter_title: Of Angels Good and Bad, their Degrees and Offices
structure_content.summary: This chapter offers a critical theological and operational distinction between benevolent angels (celestial) and malevolent spirits (infernal). It elucidates their inherent natures, hierarchical positions, and the specific conditions under which they manifest and can be engaged or commanded by the magician.

structure_content.chapter_title: Of the Orders of Wicked Demons and of their Fall and their Divers Natures
structure_content.summary: This part classifies demonic entities into nine distinct orders, such as Pseudothei and Spiritus Mendaciorum, based on their original fall from grace and their specific forms of temptation and malice. It provides crucial insights into their operational methods, weaknesses, and necessary protections for the practitioner.

structure_content.chapter_title: Of Telesmes (Talismans) and How to Make Them
structure_content.summary: This section provides detailed instructions on the astrological and magical principles underpinning talismanic creation. It explains the process of selecting propitious planetary hours and zodiacal conditions, and the precise inscription of divine names, angelic characters, and specific images to imbue talismans with desired virtues and magical effects.

structure_content.chapter_title: Of the Images of the Fixed Behenian Stars
structure_content.summary: This chapter describes the creation of images and sigils corresponding to 15 specific fixed stars, known as the Behenian Stars. It details the unique magical virtues associated with each star and provides guidance on how to harness their influences for various purposes, including material gain, protection, or specific magical operations.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Alphabet of Angels and Genii, or the Writing and Language of Heaven
structure_content.summary: This part delves into the nature of angelic communication, presenting various angelic alphabets and characters believed to be the 'language of heaven.' These scripts are crucial for the proper engraving of magical texts, talismans, and the construction of sigils that resonate with celestial intelligences.

structure_content.chapter_title: Of Numbers, Their Power and Virtue
structure_content.summary: This extensive chapter on numerology explores the mystical significance and magical properties of numbers from one to seventy. It systematically links each number to divine attributes, angelic hierarchies, planets, and elements, thereby establishing a comprehensive Qabalistic and Hermetic framework for understanding numerical correspondences in magical practice.

structure_content.chapter_title: Of the Little Tables of the Planets
structure_content.summary: This section provides illustrations and explanations of the seven classical magic squares associated with the planets (Saturn, Jupiter, Mars, Sun, Venus, Mercury, Moon). It details their corresponding divine names, ruling intelligences, and daemons, along with their sigils, outlining their practical applications for planetary magic and talisman construction.

structure_content.chapter_title: Of the Twenty-Eight Mansions of the Moon and Images
structure_content.summary: This chapter describes the 28 Lunar Mansions, outlining their astrological positions, specific offices, and associated images. It provides detailed instructions for creating these images and using them in conjunction with precise lunar astrological timings to evoke particular magical effects, especially for influencing earthly conditions and personal affairs.

structure_content.chapter_title: DR. RUDD'S NINE HIERARCHIES OF ANGELS WITH THEIR INVOCATIONS TO VISIBLE APPEARANCE (The Nine Great Celestial Keys)
structure_content.summary: This is the operative core of the treatise, detailing a structured system for invoking the nine principal angels associated with the Qabalistic Sephiroth and celestial spheres. It includes specific prayers, detailed invocations for each angel (Metratton, Raziel, Cassiel, Sachiel, Samael, Michael, Anael, Raphael, Gabriel), and precise instructions for achieving their visible appearance, incorporating their unique seals and sigils.

This section graphically illustrates and provides detailed explanations for the individual seals and sigils of each of the nine principal angels. It clarifies their Qabalistic and planetary correspondences, emphasizing their critical role as ritual tools and foci for invocation, symbolizing the divine names and angelic forces.

This chapter introduces the seven Olympian Planetary Spirits (Aratron, Bethor, Phaleg, Och, Hagith, Ophiel, Phul), describing their individual rulerships, distinctive characteristics, typical visible forms, and the specific magical operations they govern. It includes their unique sigils, offering an additional or complementary system to the angelic hierarchies.

This section describes the 'Holy Table' illustration, attributed to Peter Smart, depicting the setup for angelic invocations used by John Dee and Edward Kelley. It details elements like the mirror glass, 'Secret Sigil of Solomon,' and keys from the Angelic Alphabet, providing a visual representation of the operative tools.

key_concepts.definition: A collection of 17th-century manuscripts (Harley 6481-6484 in the British Library), primarily attributed to Dr. Thomas Rudd, which form the foundational source material for the angel magic system presented in this book.

A general term referring to the Enochian magic squares and tables detailed in the text, particularly the seven planetary tables, which are used as ritualistic grids for invoking and commanding spirits aligned with celestial bodies.

The 72-fold name of God, derived from specific Hebrew verses in Exodus (14:19-21), used to identify and invoke 72 specific angels, each associated with particular powers, offices, and a unique divine aspect.

Magically charged objects, often inscribed with divine names, planetary symbols, and sigils, created at astrologically propitious times to attract and channel specific celestial influences or powers for desired magical effects.
A specific group of 15 fixed stars believed to possess unique magical virtues, for which dedicated images and sigils can be made and consecrated to draw upon their distinct stellar powers.

Various ciphers or scripts presented in the treatise as the 'language of heaven' or 'writing of angels,' primarily used for engraving divine and angelic names on ritual implements, talismans, and for constructing sigils.

Numerical grids, each corresponding to a classical planet, containing embedded divine names, intelligences, and daemons, utilized in planetary magic to access and channel specific celestial energies and command associated spirits.

The 28 divisions of the ecliptic, each corresponding to the Moon's approximate daily motion, believed to possess specific magical virtues, images, and applications for various operations, particularly those affecting the material world.

The traditional Qabalistic and Christian classification of angels into nine distinct orders, each associated with a Sephiroth on the Tree of Life and a particular celestial sphere, forming the fundamental structure for the book's angelic invocation system.

The advanced goal of many invocations within the Rudd system, where angels or spirits physically manifest to the operator, enabling direct communication, instruction, and the fulfillment of specific requests.

Seven planetary spirits (Aratron, Bethor, Phaleg, Och, Hagith, Ophiel, Phul) distinct from the traditional angelic hierarchies, each ruling a specific planet and governing particular magical operations, with their own sigils and methods of conjuration.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined in 'A Treatise on Angel Magic' is a highly syncretic approach to achieving the visible appearance of angels and commanding spirits. It is meticulously constructed upon a theoretical foundation of Hermetic Qabalah, astrological principles, geomantic correspondences, and elements of Enochian magic. The core methodology involves the precise invocation of specific angels, especially the nine principal angels, through a structured ritual process that integrates divine names, specific prayers, consecrated seals, and propitious astrological timings. The system also encompasses detailed methods for creating talismans and magical images to harness specific celestial and planetary influences, requiring a comprehensive understanding of both angelic and demonic hierarchies for appropriate and effective interaction.
tools: Holy Table/Seal of Solomon: A consecrated ritual workspace, often diagrammatic and sometimes incorporating a mirror, serving as the central point for angelic invocations.
Seals/Sigils: Specific graphical representations of angels, planetary spirits, and divine names, functioning as critical focal points for invocation and establishing energetic contact.
Magic Squares (Planetary Tables): Diagrams, such as those for Saturn, Jupiter, etc., used in conjunction with divine names and intelligences to perform planetary-aligned magical operations.
Magic Mirror/Show Stone: A scrying device used to facilitate the perception and visible appearance of invoked spirits.
Talismans/Amulets: Physical objects crafted and consecrated according to astrological and Qabalistic principles, designed to store, attract, and project specific magical influences.
Angelic Alphabets: Specialized scripts and ciphers used for the precise inscription of divine and angelic names on ritual implements, talismans, or other magical components.
Prayers and Invocations: Specific verbal formulas and orations, carefully tailored for each angel or spirit, integrating relevant divine names, attributes, and precise requests.
rituals: Angelic Invocation: Structured rituals for each of the nine principal angels (Metratton, Raziel, Cassiel, Sachiel, Samael, Michael, Anael, Raphael, Gabriel) involving specific prayers, divine names, and the use of their individual seals to achieve visible appearance, receive instructions, or obtain assistance.

Talismanic Magic: Procedures for consecrating astrological talismans and sigils, which involve calculating precise planetary hours and zodiacal conditions, and meticulously inscribing them with divine names, angelic characters, and specific images to imbue them with desired magical virtues and effects.

Lunar Mansion Magic: Rituals focused on creating images and performing operations corresponding to the 28 Lunar Mansions. These operations are conducted under specific lunar astrological conditions to influence various earthly matters or personal circumstances.

Olympian Spirit Conjuration: Methods for invoking the seven Olympian Planetary Spirits (Aratron, Bethor, Phaleg, Och, Hagith, Ophiel, Phul) using their unique sigils and knowledge of their specific attributes and rulerships for various planetary-aligned operations.

relevant_quotes.text: This Treatise was intended as a compilation of the tradition of Angel Magic of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries, for the use of a group of practicing occultists centered around Dr. Rudd.
Observe that every part of the square, or a quarter of Heaven is governed by 18 spirits mentioned in the Schemhamphoras hereafter following, which spirits are partly good and partly evil.

The first name of the Divine Essence is EHEIE and his Idea is called Cether, which signifies a Crown, the most simple Essence of the Divinity which the Eye seeth not and is attributed to God the Father and hath his influence by the Order of Seraphims, who the Hebrews call Hayoth Hecadoth, that is, Creatures of Holiness, and then by the Primum Mobile bestoweht the gift of being to all things filling the whole Universe...
THE HOLY TABLE as laid out for the Angelic Invocations of John Dee and Edward Kelley

The Magicians made an Image hollow or Telesme of Quicksilver, with the figure of a handsome young man bearded on it, then the Genius will speak with a barren voice yet very audible. Sometimes Derachiel, or Ambiel or Gabriel will descend upon the Telesme.

Phul changeth all metals into Silver in word and deed, governeth Lunary things, healeth the dropsy, he giveth spirits of the water who do serve men in a corporeal visible form and maketh men to live 300 years if God permit.

critical_analysis.relevance: This book is profoundly relevant for serious students and practitioners of Western Esotericism, particularly those immersed in the historical development and practical application of Solomonic and Enochian magical traditions. It provides a unique, accessible transcription of a pivotal 17th-century grimoire, thereby bridging classical magical theory with operative ritual. The treatise offers deep insight into the Rosicrucian context of angelic invocation and the syncretic nature of early modern occultism, integrating Qabalah, astrology, and geomancy. Its meticulously detailed instructions and comprehensive directories of spirits make it an indispensable resource for advanced ritual work.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of advanced practitioners and dedicated academic researchers in Western Esotericism, occultism, and magic. This text is not suitable for beginners due to the inherent complexity of the material, the assumed familiarity with Qabalistic and astrological correspondences, and the potential spiritual and psychological challenges associated with commanding spirits. Individuals with a strong background in historical grimoires, angelic magic, planetary magic, and the works of figures like John Dee, Edward Kelley, and Johannes Trithemius will find this book particularly valuable and rewarding.
